newsitem.title: GERMANY: Gene maize seed supplier seeks early sales in EU.
newsitem.headline: Gene maize seed supplier seeks early sales in EU.

text.p: Novartis Agro GmbH expects permission soon to supply gene-altered maize seeds to the European market now that France has cleared such products for sale, company spokesman Joerg Albrecht said on Thursday.
"The French move legalises imports of genetically altered maize, now gene-altered maize seeds need to be made registered varieties," he said in a telephone interview.
"We're expecting this to happen very soon in France and Spain and inclusion in the list of EU registered varieties would be the next step."
The French farm ministry this week authorised the marketing of maize genetically adapted by the Swiss firm Ciba Geigy to resist the corn borer pest.
Formed last year when Ciba-Geigy and Sandoz AG merged into the worldwide Swiss Novartis group, Novartis Agro is one of eight firms within life sciences company Novartis Deutschland.

Gene maize is already grown in the U.S., and its registration in Europe could take two months, Albrecht said. That would mean seeds arriving late into the 1997 March/April European planting season, but not too late to test their performance.
France, where the demand to allow transgenic maize on the EU market arose, made its decision on the basis of mandatory labelling of gene-altered organisms and derived products.

Novartis Seeds GmbH would sell the Ciba maize in Germany. Albrecht said he hoped that farmers in Bavaria, Baden-Wuerttemberg and southern Hesse, where the corn borer was most damaging, would recognise its advantages.

Novartis was in contact with environmental group Greenpeace, which opposes gene- altered maize on the grounds it could harm human health and which has vowed to fight cultivation after an unsuccessful attempt to stop imports from the U.S.
Albrecht said, "We don't need to hide our maize, it is a good product, we will label the seeds and we respect consumers' wish to opt for or against it."

Novartis also respected German farm union DBV's calls for the separate planting and handling of genetically modified and traditional maize, although this might not be possible under current farm practices.
Novartis had scheduled discussions with legislators, scientists, farmers, consumers in the starch industry and the grain and feeds trade in order to gain acceptance for gene-altered maize.
Novartis was the first firm, but not alone, in seeking approval for corn borer resistant maize in Europe.
In the U.S., at least two Ciba competitors were expected to be given approval for 1997/98 sales after gene maize accounted for just 0.5 percent of the total 1996/97 crop area.
Ciba maize cost about 20 percent more than good quality non-modified maize in the U.S., and the price in Europe was also set to be 20 to 25 percent higher.
"But farmers will begin to save money on the basis of an anticipated five to 10 percent borer pest occurrence, and relatively more if the pest is more widespread," Albrecht said.
Sales opportunities in Germany were modest compared with southern European countries. Germany grows just 2.9 million tonnes of maize a year.
